results.title: Our changing cities - can they be saved?
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and William Kay
results.brief_description: A short history of the development of cities in the United States. Accounts for the social forces and movements which have shaped modern cities, and describes city life of the past and present. Designed for children.

results.title: Our century: invaders
results.creator_credit: Will Davies, Nine Network, Australian Film Commission, Film Australia, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia, Mark Hamlyn and Alec Morgan
results.brief_description: This episode from ‘Our Century’ and hosted by Ray Martin examines the infestations that have cursed Australia since white settlement. It covers issues such as why some animals and insects were introduced and how we now deal with their devastating effects on the environment.

results.title: Our bushfire menace
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hansen and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Wild Life”.
A classroom account of destruction caused by bushfires. In the Australian bush, fire is the greatest menace to wild animal life; on the farm, fire destroys cattle, sheep and homesteads and helps the start of soil erosion. The causes of bushfires are shown and methods of prevention listed. The film concludes with a blackboard revision of the content of the film.

results.title: Our Botanical History
results.creator_credit: Mark Falzon, Michael Edols and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Judy West of the Australian National Library offers an insight into Joseph Banks’ “Florilegium” which captures one of the world’s finest natural history collections. Host Sue Henckel then travels to far north Queensland where botanic artist, Betty Hinton, is continuing the work of Banks’ artist, Sydney Parkinson, which was begun two centuries ago.
